items.title: Datacenters selling power back to the grid? Don’t bet on it, say operators
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Bit barns in Dublin doubled as battery farms, the rest of the world isn’t buying it

Analysis  The idea of datacenters feeding power back into the electricity grid during peak demand may sound promising, but operators say it's unlikely to catch on beyond a few trials in Ireland because of the cost and technical complexity involved.…

items.title: Brit soldiers tune radio waves to fry drone swarms for pennies

Truck-mounted demonstration weapon costs 10p a pop, says MOD

British soldiers have successfully taken down drones with a radio-wave weapon.…

items.title: Bank of England flirts with offline digital dosh

items.title: Competition boffin launches class action against Google UK over search dominance

items.summary:
Alleges £5B in harm caused by Android deals, anticompetitive actions

A British academic has launched a class-action suit against Google, alleging abuse of its market dominance in online search caused £5 billion ($6.6 billion) of damage to advertisers.…

items.title: Daddy of a mistake by GoDaddy took Zoom offline for about 90 minutes
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Manager of the .us namespace managed to block zoom.us

items.title: Heat can make Li-Ion batteries explode. Or restore their capacity, say Chinese boffins
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Future chargers could re-arrange battery chemistry to make them live longer

Researchers at China’s Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering have found a way to restore the energy density of old Lithium-Ion batteries by heating them to over 150°C.…

items.title: Whistleblower describes DOGE IT dept rampage at America's labor watchdog
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Ignored infosec rules, exfiltrated data … then the mysterious login attempts from a Russian IP address began – claim

Democratic lawmakers are calling for an investigation after a tech staffer at the US National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) blew the whistle on the cost-trimming DOGE's activities at the employment watchdog – which the staffer claims included being granted superuser status in contravention of standard operating procedures, exfiltrating data, and seemingly leaking credentials to someone with a Russian IP address.…

items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Give Elon an inch and he'll take thousands of miles ... allegedly

Tesla has been accused of somehow sneakily altering a customer's odometer to hasten the end of his vehicle's warranty period.…

Ah yes, the courts, that'll totally work

World War Fee  President Trump's reign of tariffs has been challenged on the left and right by the State of California and the Liberty Justice Center.…

Redmond talks up preview of AI agents navigating apps through the UI

items.summary:
Just make it 420.69 and be done with it, Mr President

Microsoft rewards those who patch early with bricks hurled through its operating system

Keeping with its rich history of updates that break Windows in unexpected ways, Microsoft has warned that two recent patches for Windows 11 24H2 are triggering blue screen crashes.…

items.title: Signalgate chats vanish from CIA chief phone

items.summary:
Extraordinary rendition of data, or just dropped it out of a helicopter?

CIA Director John Ratcliffe's smartphone has almost no trace left of the infamous Signalgate chat – the one in which he and other top US national security officials discussed a secret upcoming military operation in a group Signal conversation a journalist was inadvertently added to.…

items.title: Microsoft admits it's not you, Classic Outlook can be a real CPU, power hog sometimes
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Bug or migration strategy for New Outlook, we wonder

Far be it from us to suggest Microsoft is trying to force people onto its New Outlook application, but it has admitted Classic Outlook occasionally and mysteriously turns into a system resource hog.…

It's been a little over a year since Adobe abandoned its plans to purchase web-based design tool Figma. Now, the smaller of the two app makers is bucking market uncertainty by filing for an IPO.…

Uncertainty is the new certainty

AWS estimates that half of the workloads Microsoft enterprise customers run on Azure would migrate to its own datacenters if only the licensing costs of doing so were not prohibitively high and a competitive deterrent.…

items.summary:
Dutch lithography king sticks to €35B forecast despite investor jitters

Euro tech giant ASML hit its revenue guidance last quarter and still expects the coffers to swell this year, but order bookings are down as Trump's tariff turmoil casts uncertainty over the entire industry.…

Vintage phishing varietal has improved with age

Russia never stops using proven tactics, and its Cozy Bear, aka APT 29, cyber-spies are once again trying to lure European diplomats into downloading malware with a phony invitation to a lux event.…

items.title: Legacy tech is the gift that keeps billing for UK's tax collector
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
£5.2B more thrown at the never-ending quest to modernize HMRC

In 2022, the UK's tax collector put £4.5 billion ($5.9 billion) on the table to help its applications become "less dependent upon legacy technologies." The extent to which His Majesty's Revenue & Customs (HMRC) achieved that goal is debatable, but there is no doubt it intends to spend up to £5.2 billion ($6.9 billion) more to continue the job.…

It's not DNS. It can't be DNS? Right?

items.summary:
It involves a number close to three or six depending on the pickle you're in

800K? Make that double, and we'll need a double, too, for the pain

items.summary:
Who said this opt-out approach is OK with GDPR, was it Llama 4, hmm?

Meta on Monday said it plans to start training its AI models using public posts and comments shared by adults in the EU, along with interactions users have with its chatbot.…

items.title: 4chan, the 'internet’s litter box,' appears to have been pillaged by rival forum

items.summary:
Source code, moderator info, IP addresses, more allegedly swiped and leaked

Thousands of 4chan users reported outages Monday night amid rumors on social media that the edgy anonymous imageboard had been ransacked by an intruder, with someone on a rival forum claiming to have leaked its source code, moderator identities, and users' IP addresses.…

items.title: All right, you can have one: DOGE access to Treasury IT OK'd judge

items.summary:
Login green-lit for lone staffer if he’s trained, papered up, won’t pull an Elez

A federal judge has partly lifted an injunction against Elon Musk's Trump-blessed cost-trimming DOGE unit, allowing one staff member to access sensitive US Treasury payment systems. This access includes personally identifiable financial information tied to millions of Americans.…

items.title: Exchange Server 2019 has less than six months of support left in the tank

Microsoft has warned administrators that less than half a year remains until support ends for Exchange Server 2016 and 2019. However, the follow-up, Exchange Server SE, won't arrive for another few months.…

items.title: Why wait to build a datacenter when you can just unpack one?

items.summary:

A cyberspy crew or individual with ties to China's Ministry of State Security has infected global organizations with a remote access trojan (RAT) that's "even better" than Cobalt Strike, using this stealthy backdoor to enable its espionage and access resale campaigns.…

items.summary:
Car hire biz takes your privacy seriously, though

The first Intel-based Mac was 19 years ago, but new versions of apps for both Classic Mac OS and PowerPC Mac OS X still occasionally appear, and we are here for it.…

items.title: Windows Recovery Environment update fails successfully, says Microsoft
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
See no error, hear no error, speak no error

The three wise Microsoft monkeys have spoken. If Windows Update displayed an error after installing the April 2025 Windows Recovery Environment release, you didn't see anything. Best to ignore it and move on.…
